newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Boycotted Zambian polls draw to close peacefully.
newsitem.headline: Boycotted Zambian polls draw to close peacefully.

text.p: Zambian elections drew peacefully towards their close on Monday, marred by an opposition boycott and disapproval from Western donors who fear it was largely a cosmetic exercise in democracy.

President Frederick Chiluba is set for a second term after barring a challenge from his only strong rival, "Father of the Nation" Kenneth Kaunda, whom he beat in the first free elections in 1991 on a free-market and democracy platform.
Enraged, Kaunda's United National Independence Party (UNIP) walked out of parliament and led a seven-party boycott of the presidential and parliamentary polls they call a farce.
Chiluba, 53, voted in his Copperbelt region stronghold and Kaunda, 72, went to play his favourite sport, golf.
Kaunda said he would call for the results to be annulled but would denounce violence as a means of change.
"These people did more damage in five years than I did in 27," he told reporters aid as he teed off. "But violence is not my way."
Voting, held up in many polling stations by bureaucratic bungles, was extended into the evening in some places to enable everyone queuing to vote. No official western observers came.
Police said the day passed without much-feared violence.
Final results were not due until Tuesday or Wednesday.
"Turnout appears to have been very, very low," said UNIP central committee member Proff Desai. "It was hundreds rather than thousands at all of the polling stations I visited."
State officials said voting was brisk despite a flawed registration system that omitted half the 4.6 million adults.
"Voters in their numbers braved the rain to vote and are throwing election boycotts to the wind," state radio said.

Kaunda, who led Zambia to independence from Britain in 1964 and founded a one-party state on African-Christian-socialist "humanism", was ruled out under a new constitution passed in May by Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) because his parents were not Zambian-born. They were from Malawi.
Whatever the outcome of the vote, political strife and economic hardship are set to intensify.
UNIP has launched a campaign of civil disobedience and predicted Chiluba's downfall within six months, assuming he beats his four remaining challengers who stood on Monday.

Foreign donors, upset by the bar on Kaunda and by other political developments in what had been a model of African progress, have frozen aid which helped copper-rich but impoverished Zambia cope with its $6.4 billion external debt.
"Many of the hard-won gains of the last five years of reform are now at risk from the donor freeze," said the Standard Chartered bank group's September report on Zambia.
The World Bank says privatisation and economic reform in landlocked Zambia are second to none in Africa.

After the vote donors will face a dilemma -- to watch Zambia's economic promise fade away; or to eat humble pie and resume aid, having failed, like South African President Nelson Mandela, to make Chiluba reopen dialogue with UNIP.
Ironically most political analysts believe Chiluba would easily have beaten Kaunda in a free contest between the parties, which they said differ little on policy nowadays.
